title: Is it possible to find a cycle in a directed graph using BFS? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes, BFS finds you cycles. Suppose there is a cycle in the graph. In BFS, you are iteratively traversing all incident out-edges of a vertex. At some instance during BFS, one such incident out-edge will point to an already visited vertex — congrats, you have found a cycle!

Given a single node and asked to detect if the graph loops back to that specific node. Don’t see why not, but a DFS may be more efficient. An un-directed graph may be quicker with a BFS, as it would meet half way.
